meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Argentine Wins U.S. Open Ángel Cabrera of Argentina won the United States Open with a final round of 69 in Oakmont, Pa. Tiger Woods, a two-time Open champion, was left to admire Cabrera's trophy when he fell short of forcing a playoff by one shot after missing a birdie putt on the final hole. Jim Furyk, who was trying to win his second United States Open title, tied Woods for second.
PAGE D1

Yankees Roll Past Mets Alex Rodriguez hit a two-run homer in the first inning, and the Yankees never looked back in an 8-2 victory over the Mets, their 11th victory in 12 games. The Yankees' starter, Chien-Ming Wang, gave up two runs over eight and two-thirds innings as the teams split their six-game season series.
SPORTSMONDAY
Reservations on Demand Restaurants have gone unabashedly high-tech, with more than 7,000 worldwide now taking reservations over the Web.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1
Parking Fees in Traffic Plan? The fine print of the mayor's congestion pricing plan suggests that some people may have to pay to park near their own homes.
PAGE B1

French Conservatives Win The conservative party of President Nicolas Sarkozy won a solid victory in parliamentary elections, but failed to trounce the Socialist opposition as had been predicted. The Socialists gained 36 seats and Mr. Sarkozy's party lost 45.
PAGE A6

New Palestinian Government President Mahmoud Abbas swore in an emergency Palestinian government at his headquarters, as the split between Fatah and Hamas officials deepened. Meanwhile, rockets fired from Lebanon landed in Israel, but caused no casualties.
PAGE A3
Gianfranco Ferré Dies at 62 The Italian fashion designer, noted for his signature ready-to-wear collection and for opening French haute couture to foreign-born designers, died in Milan.
PAGE A17

Mostly Tie-Dyed Festival Although the reunited Police, featuring Sting, right, were one of several headliners from way off the jam-band circuit, the Bonnaroo music festival in Tennessee was, as usual, a basically hippie affair with long hair, peasant dresses and flowers everywhere. A review by Jon Pareles.
THE ARTS, PAGE E1

Argentine Wins U.S. Open Ángel Cabrera of Argentina won the United States Open with a final round of 69 in Oakmont, Pa. Tiger Woods, a two-time Open champion, was left to admire Cabrera's trophy when he fell short of forcing a playoff by one shot after missing a birdie putt on the final hole. Jim Furyk, who was trying to win his second United States Open title, tied Woods for second.
PAGE D1

Yankees Roll Past Mets Alex Rodriguez hit a two-run homer in the first inning, and the Yankees never looked back in an 8-2 victory over the Mets, their 11th victory in 12 games. The Yankees' starter, Chien-Ming Wang, gave up two runs over eight and two-thirds innings as the teams split their six-game season series.

PAGE B1

French Conservatives Win The conservative party of President Nicolas Sarkozy won a solid victory in parliamentary elections, but failed to trounce the Socialist opposition as had been predicted. The Socialists gained 36 seats and Mr. Sarkozy's party lost 45.
PAGE A6

New Palestinian Government President Mahmoud Abbas swore in an emergency Palestinian government at his headquarters, as the split between Fatah and Hamas officials deepened. Meanwhile, rockets fired from Lebanon landed in Israel, but caused no casualties.
PAGE A3

PAGE A17

Mostly Tie-Dyed Festival Although the reunited Police, featuring Sting, right, were one of several headliners from way off the jam-band circuit, the Bonnaroo music festival in Tennessee was, as usual, a basically hippie affair with long hair, peasant dresses and flowers everywhere. A review by Jon Pareles.
